BOX.NAME: Data Services Consultant Schedule
BOX.DESCRIPTION:
Data Services consultants are able to provide walk-in assistance when available, however scheduling an appointment ahead of time is highly recommended. For more information on Data Services consultants please refer to the Data Services staff page.

A calendar listing when consultants are scheduled to sit at the desks within the Data Services lab can be found below. Please note that the consultants listed in purple are students while those listed in orange are full-time, professional staff members.

BOX.NAME: NYU Data Services
BOX.DESCRIPTION:
Service Alert:
Please note that during the summer months we have fewer available staff in some areas. We'll do our best to provide you service in a timely fashion.

Data Services is a joint service of New York University's Division of Libraries and Information Technology Services to support quantitative, qualitative, and geographical research at NYU. Data Services offers access to specialty software packages for statistical analysis, geographic information systems (GIS), and qualitative data analysis. We provide training and support as well as consulting expertise for many aspects of the research data lifecycle including access, analysis, collection development, data management, and data preservation. Data Services is part of Elmer Holmes Bobst Library's Research Commons. Our staff offices and main lab are located on the 5th floor of the library.  

The Data Services lab is equipped with 26 lab workstations where faculty, students, and staff can receive consultations and access our workstations.  

Consultation is available by appointment through our online appointment form, via email at <data.services@nyu.edu>, by telephone at 212-998-3434, or on a walk-in basis. Information on upcoming tutorials, clinics, and other events is available in our News tab above.

BOX.NAME: Computer Use Policy
BOX.DESCRIPTION:
Data Services lab computers may be used by library patrons on a walk-in basis. However, workstations can be reserved by NYU faculty, staff, and students for data and statistical projects by contacting a consultant or using the web appointment form. Users working without reservations will be asked to relocate to another workstation when a computer has been reserved for project use.  Use of the Data Services lab is governed by the following guidelines:

Bobst Library Conduct Code:
http://library.nyu.edu/about/code.html

Responsibilities of All NYU Computer, Data, and Network Users
http://www.nyu.edu/its/policies/respon.html

Policy on Responsible Use of NYU Computers & Data
http://www.nyu.edu/its/policies/responsibleuse.html

BOX.NAME: Data Management
BOX.DESCRIPTION: Data Services staff is prepared to assist researchers in developing data management plans. Please see our guide which gives background information, describes the elements of a data management plan, lists data management requirements, describes some data repositories and provides contact information for professionals in the Data Services and Libraries who can help researchers with their data management plans.

BOX.NAME: Data Services Tutorials
BOX.DESCRIPTION:
Data Services tutorials are typically 60-90 minute sessions that focus on the essential components of our supported software packages. To see the full list of Library classes please visit the Library's classes page. Please note unregistered and waitlisted patrons are welcome to attend our tutorials and will only be asked to leave if there is not enough space to accommodate the attendees who have registered for the session.

A calendar of Data Services' scheduled tutorials and clinics can be found below. The calendar is updated on a monthly basis.

To let us know what tutorials you would like to see in the future, please fill out this survey.

**This software package is installed on all Data Services lab computers but there is a restriction on the number of users who may use the software concurrently.

BOX.NAME: Data Services
BOX.DESCRIPTION:
Data Services offers a wide variety of services in support of quantitative, qualitative, and geographical research, including:

Research Consultation

  • One-on-one and group consultation is available via appointment, walk-in, email or phone during Data Services' staffed hours.
    • Assistance is available for all of Data Services' supported software packages as well as for getting started using NYU's High Performance Computing clusters.

Access to Facilities and Software

  • Data Services lab workstations, loaded with specialty research software packages, are available for walk-in use on a first-come, first-serve basis.
  • Reservations are also available during Data Services' staffed hours on 6 lab machines (DATA16, DATA17, DATA18, DATA19, DATA25 and DATA26).

Instruction and Training Resources

  • Data Services provides instructional tutorials on select software packages each semester.
  • Data Services also provides tutorial documentation and recommended external training resources.

Data Reference & Collections

  • Data Services provides access to and assistance in locating numeric and spatial datasets.

Data Management

  • Consultation is available for forming data management plans for inclusion in grant proposals.

BOX.NAME: Data Services Tutorial: MATLAB - Beyond Basics
Frequently Asked Questions
BOX.DESCRIPTION:
General Information about the NYU Data Services

  • How can I keep up-to-date on Data Services tutorials, events and announcements?

    Data Services sends out regular (approximately one message every 6 weeks) announcements about service changes, special events, tutorials and job opportunities. via the "statistics" listserv. To subscribe to the "statistics" list, select it from the listserv section in NYUHome or send a blank, plain text, email to join-statistics@lists.nyu.edu.

     

  • Is the Data Services lab open at night or the on the weekends?

    The Data Services lab is not currently staffed beyond 8:00pm (Mondays and Tuesdays), 6:00pm (Wednesdays, Thursdays and Fridays) or during the weekends; however, the Data Services lab workstations are available for use whenever the Library's stacks are open.

     

  • I would like access to or support with a software package that is not listed as a Data Services supported software package. Will Data Services start supporting this software package?

    Data Services supports software packages upon demand, so please email data.services@nyu.edu with details about any software package(s) you believe Data Services should be supporting. Also note that we are glad to install any research-related open source, or freely available, software packages onto the Data Services lab workstation(s).

     

Tutorials and Training Resources

  • I missed or cannot attend a Data Services tutorial. When will Data Services offer another tutorial on this subject?

    The current tutorial schedule can be found on the Data Services Tutorials tab; if you cannot attend any of the remaining tutorials then the next fleet of tutorials will likely be scheduled at the start of the following semester. However, if there is enough demand for an additional tutorial then we will gladly provide one; to keep up-to-date on new tutorials please subscribe to the statistics listserv.

     

  • Can I schedule a tutorial for my class?

    Yes, Data Services is able to provide specialized tutorials for classes upon request. To schedule a tutorial for your class please fill out the Data Services appointment form with details about the tutorial you are seeking.

     

  • How can I learn how to use one of your supported software packages?

    Data Services offers introductory tutorials in most of our supported software packages. While participants should not expect to fully understand how to use a software package by attending one these tutorials, they will become more comfortable with the interface and some common applications of the software. Data Services also provides links to a wide variety of  instructional resources on the training and documentation page. However, it should be noted that some supported software packages require more than a technical understanding of the software; if you are struggling with the conceptual component of statistical analysis then we recommend enrolling in a NYU statistics course and/or consulting appropriate texts.

     

Questions About Our Services

  • Does Data Services offer statistical tutoring services?

    No, Data Services does not provide tutoring services. If you are having difficulties with the methodological component or conceptual aspect of quantitative research then we suggest talking to your advisor, professor, and/or teaching assistant. Additionally, the Data Services training and documentation page may offer some useful resources and some Data Services consultants may be willing to negotiate private tutoring sessions outside of Data Services.

     

  • Can Data Services tell me which statistical tests I should conduct for my research or if I have correctly conducted my research?

    No, for a number of reasons the Data Services staff will not, or in most cases cannot, tell patrons which statistical tests would be best for their research, however they are glad to talk to anyone about their research and will do their best to recommend a few possibilities to explore. In most cases Data Services consultants recommend that students meet with their academic adviser(s), and/or other faculty members, and consult any relevant literature within their field.

     

  • Do your services cost money?

    No, Data Services provides all of our services free of charge to all current NYU students, faculty, and staff members.

     

Employment Opportunities and Hiring Information

  • How can I become a Data Services student consultant?

    Data Services typically posts job opportunities on the statistics listserv, as well as on a few departmental lists, however students are always welcome to send a resume and cover letter to data.services@nyu.edu; resumes received by Data Services will be held on file and referred to when positions open and/or when Data Services is contacted by researchers who are looking to hire consultants.

     

  • Does Data Services offer any internship opportunities?

    Yes, Data Services offers semester-long unpaid internship opportunities to students who are looking to gain experience assisting researchers with quantitative, qualitative, and/or geographical research methods and software packages. In addition to gaining research experience, Data Services interns frequently transition into paid positions as a student consultants at the Data Services after completing their internship. Data Services will typically post internship opportunities on the statistics listserv, however interested students are always welcome to send a resume and cover letter to data.services@nyu.edu.

     

  • I am looking to hire research assistant(s), can Data Services recommend any students who may be interested?

    Depending on the assistance you are looking for, Data Services can forward the opportunity to our Data Services student consultants and, in some cases, advertise the position on our News page. If you are interested in hiring a research assistance please email data.services@nyu.edu with a description of your research and the role(s) you are looking to fill.

BOX.NAME: Appointment Form

PAGE.NAME: NYU GIS Services and Spatial Data Resources

BOX.NAME: Data Services News
BOX.DESCRIPTION: <iframe src="http://nyudataservices.wordpress.com/" style="width: 100%; height: 1750px"></iframe>

BOX.NAME: Employment Opportunities Currently Available
BOX.DESCRIPTION: There are no positions available currently. However, Data Services is always looking for bright individuals. If you are a full-time student with extensive experience of conducting academic research using one or more of our supported software packages and have a desire to improve your knowledge of research methodologies, please email a resume and a cover letter to data.services@nyu.edu.

BOX.NAME: About Data Services Employment
BOX.DESCRIPTION:
Data Services student consultants work in the Data Services lab on the 5th floor of Bobst Library, providing quantitative, qualitative, and geospatial research support to the faculty, staff, and students of NYU. As a Data Services student consultant you will have opportunity to gain valuable research experience across multiple academic fields, gain instructional skills and experience, and develop professional connections with faculty, staff and professionals at NYU.

Responsibilities of our student consultants include providing quantitative, qualitative, and/or geospatial analysis consultation on a walk-in and appointment basis, leading Data Services instructional tutorials, preparing training documentation, and participating in select projects. The starting hourly rate is $16.00. Consultants are expected to be available for 10-15 hours per week.

BOX.NAME: Student Consultant Positions
BOX.DESCRIPTION:
1. Quantitative Data Analysis Student Consultant

2. GIS Student Consultant

 

1. Quantitative Data Analysis Student Consultant

This is an On-Campus, Paid Job - $16/hour, 10-15 hours/week

 

Position Overview: Data Services student consultants work in the Data Services lab on the 5th floor of Bobst Library, providing quantitative, qualitative, and geospatial research support to the faculty, staff, and students of NYU.

 

Duties include: providing quantitative analysis consultation on a walk-in and appointment basis, leading Data Services instructional tutorials, preparing training documentation, and participating in select projects. The starting hourly rate is $16.00.

 

Benefits: Data Services student consultants have the opportunity to gain valuable research experience across multiple academic fields, gain instructional skills and experience, and develop professional connections with faculty, staff and professionals at NYU.  

Qualifications: Full-time students wishing to be considered should have experience conducting quantitative academic research with statistical software (SPSS, Stata, SAS, R, or MATLAB) and should have proficiency with commonly used quantitative research methods. Applicants should also have the desire to improve their knowledge of research methodologies. Consultants will be expected to be available for 10-15 hours per week for the remainder of the Spring semester, be available to work during the Summer and continue into the Fall 2013 semester.

How to Apply:

1. Put "Quantitative Data Analysis Student Consultant_Your Full Name" in the subject line.

2. Please email your cover letter, resume to Data Services (data.services@nyu.edu).

2. GIS Student Consultant

 

This is an On-Campus, Paid Job - $16/hour, 10-20 hours/week

 

Eligibility:

- Enrolled full-time in an under-graduate or graduate degree program at NYU.

- Basic knowledge of ArcGIS, and desire to learn advanced techniques in GIS as well as about other software packages supported by DS.

- Excellent communication, organizational and public service skills.

- Adaptable to dynamic work environment and varied requests from patrons.

- Desire to improve knowledge of research methodologies.

 

Responsibilities:

- Assist clients/patrons (student, faculty and staff) with GIS and mapping queries via appointments, walk-ins and telephone.

- Assist, update and/or conduct instructional tutorials in ArcGIS, Geocoding, Google Earth, etc.

- Gain advanced GIS skills in support of services provided  by DS.

- Distribute ArcGIS software.

- Document every client interactions.

- Perform administrative tasks as directed by DSS Admin.

- Research and document external resources for spatial datasets.

- Assist DS Staff on internal GIS projects.

- Promote GIS services at NYU.

 

The starting hourly rate is $16.00. Consultants are expected to be available for 10-20 hours per week for the remainder of the Spring semester, be available to work during the Summer and continue into the Fall 2013 semester, based on the performance and eligibility criteria.

 

Student will have the opportunity to collaborate with, and learn from, faculty, staff and students GIS projects and learn GIS applications.

 

How to Apply:

1. Put "GIS Consultant Application_Your Full Name" in the subject line.

2. Please email your cover letter, resume and GIS work samples to Data Services (data.services@nyu.edu).

Good Luck!

BOX.NAME: Full-Time Employment Opportunities Currently Available
BOX.DESCRIPTION:
Qualitative Data Analysis & Survey Research Specialist
 
New York University's Data Services, a joint NYU Libraries and NYU Information Technology Services (ITS) service, is seeking a full-time Qualitative Data Analysis & Survey Research Specialist to provide computing support to faculty, students, and staff at NYU in the areas of qualitative data analysis (QDA) and web survey research.
 
Responsibilties
The QDA & Survey Research Specialist will be working in a vibrant and collaborative environment on a team that supports all phases of the data lifecycle for quantitative, qualitative, and geospatial research. Data Services offers access to specialty software packages, software training and support, and consulting expertise for many aspects of numeric, qualitative, and spatial data for research, including data access, analysis, collection, data management, and preservation. The successful candidate will work closely with Division of Libraries professionals and faculty as well as with colleagues in NYU Information Technology Services (ITS) with respect to referrals, service development, technology, standards, resources and projects.  
Eligibility
 
Qualifications/Required Education:
  • Bachelor's degree or equivilant experience in a social science or other related field  
Preferred Education:
  • Graduate degree in a social science or related discipline requiring interaction with statistical software and data sets.  
Required Experience:
  • 1-3 years' experience conducting or assisting with qualitative academic research with Atlas.ti and/or NVivo QDA software. 1-3 years' experience conducting or assisting with research utilizing web survey tools such as Qualtrics, Survey Monkey, or others.  
Preferred Experience:
  • Experience teaching QDA or survey software packages and/or research methods. Experience in an academic environment, preferably in IT and/or Libraries.  
Required Knowledge, Skills, and Abilities: 
  • Excellent public service, communication, organizational, and interpersonal skills.
  • Ability to work courteously and effectively with patrons and colleagues in a collaborative team environment.
  • Proficiency with commonly used qualitative and survey research methods.  
Preferred Knowledge, Skills, and Abilities:
  • Basic understanding of geographic information systems (GIS) and/or quantitative data analysis.  
For more details and to apply, see: www.nyucareers.com/applicants/Central?quickFind=57114

BOX.NAME: Student Consultant Positions
BOX.DESCRIPTION:
About Data Services

  • Data Services student consultants work in the Data Services lab on the 5th floor of Bobst Library, providing quantitative, qualitative, and geospatial research support to the faculty, staff, and students of NYU. As a Data Services student consultant you will have opportunity to gain valuable research experience across multiple academic fields, gain instructional skills and experience, and develop professional connections with faculty, staff and professionals at NYU.
  • Responsibilities of our student consultants include providing quantitative, qualitative, and/or geospatial analysis consultation on a walk-in and appointment basis, leading Data Services instructional tutorials, preparing training documentation, and participating in select projects. The starting hourly rate is $16.00. Consultants are expected to be available for 10-15 hours per week.

Current Openings

  • There are no positions available currently. However, Data Services is always looking for bright individuals. If you are a full-time student with extensive experience of conducting academic research using one or more of our supported software packages and have a desire to improve your knowledge of research methodologies, please email a resume and a cover letter to data.services@nyu.edu.

BOX.NAME: Full-Time Positions
BOX.DESCRIPTION:
1. Data Services Adjunct Quantitative Data Analysis Specialist

2. Data Services Adjunct  Geographic Information Systems (GIS) Specialist

1. Data Services Adjunct Librarian: Quantitative Data Analysis Specialist

Description:

New York University's (NYU) Data Services, a joint ITS and Library service, is seeking a part-time (20-25 hours per week) Quantitative Data Services Adjunct Specialist to provide quantitative research computing support to faculty, students, and staff at NYU.

Duties include providing consultation on a walk-in and appointment basis, leading Data Services instructional tutorials, and preparing Data Services training documentation, with a primary focus on statistical software packages such as Stata, R, MATLAB, SAS and SPSS. Providing statistical programming support to academic researchers. Coordinating with other consultants in Data Services to provide support to academic researchers. Initiating and contributing to Data Services projects

Qualifications:

Required:

  • Bachelor's degree in one of the following fields: statistics, sociology, psychology, political science, economics or another field where in-depth knowledge of quantitative methods and tools is indicated.
  • 1-3 years relevant experience or an equivalent combination
  • 1-3 years of experience conducting quantitative academic research with at least two of the following statistical software packages: Stata, R, MATLAB, SAS and SPSS.
  • Proficiency of commonly used statistical and data-oriented methods, including: data cleaning, t-tests, ANOVA, linear regression and generalized linear models.
  • Excellent public service, communication, organizational and interpersonal skills.

Preferred:

  • Master's degree in Statistics, Sociology, Economics, Psychology, Mathematics, Political Science or related quantitative-focused field.
  • Experience teaching quantitative software packages and/or research methods
  • Experience in an academic environment, preferably in IT and/or Libraries
  • Familiarity with a variety of statistical methods, such as: factor analysis, panel data analysis, categorical data analysis, nonparametric techniques, multi-level modeling, structural equation modeling and classification methods
  • Knowledge of computer science concepts including data structures and algorithms; experience programming with a high-level language like Python, Julia or C++
  • Basic understanding of geographic information systems (GIS), qualitative data analysis and survey research methods
  • Experience submitting batch jobs on high performance computing systems

New York University Libraries:

Libraries at New York University serve the school’s 40,000 students and faculty and contain more than 5 million volumes. The Libraries supports NYU’s vision to become the first true Global Network University by collaborating and providing services to our global academic centers and “portal campuses” in Abu Dhabi and Shanghai.   New York University Libraries is a member of the Association of Research Libraries, the OCLC Research Library Partnership, and the HathiTrust. The Libraries participates in a variety of consortia and collaborates closely with Columbia University Libraries and the New York Public Library through the Manhattan Research Library Consortium. For the NYU Libraries Mission and Strategic Plan go to http://library.nyu.edu/about/Strategic_Plan.pdf 

Salary/Benefits:

Salary commensurate with experience and background.

To Apply:

Please email a resume and cover letter describing your qualifications and interest in the position to data.services@nyu.edu. The search will remain open until filled.

NYU’s Division of Libraries embraces diversity and is committed to attracting qualified candidates who also embrace and value diversity and inclusivity.

NYU is an Equal Opportunity/Affirmative Action Employer.

2. Data Services Adjunct  Geographic Information Systems (GIS) Specialist

Description:

 

New York University's Data Services, a joint ITS and Library service, is seeking a part-time (20-25 hours per week) Data Services Adjunct GIS Specialist to provide GIS and mapping support to faculty, students, and staff. Data Services Adjunct GIS Specialist will join the team of GIS and data professionals in enhancing geospatial support at NYU.     

 

Duties Include:

 

  • Providing consultation on a walk-in and appointment basis, leading Data Services instructional tutorials, and preparing Data Services training documentation, with a primary focus on the ArcGIS suite of geographic information systems software, and secondary focus on other GIS tools like ERDAS Imagine, Google Earth and other open source tools.

  • Coordinating with other consultants in Data Services to provide support to academic researchers.

  • Initiating and contributing to Data Services projects.

  • Keeping up-to-date on technical advances and methodological trends in GIS and geospatial research.

  • Contributing to NYU’s ongoing efforts towards supporting the life-cycle of spatial data (collection to preservation).

  • Performing various administrative duties associated with managing an academic facility.

 

Eligibility:

 

Required Education: Bachelor's degree in geography, urban planning or another field utilizing GIS methods and technology.

 

Preferred Education: Master's degree in geography, urban planning or another field utilizing GIS methods and technology.

Required Experience:

 

  • 1-3 years relevant experience or an equivalent combination.

  • 1-3 years of experience conducting geospatial academic research with ArcGIS suite, and familiarity with one or more of the following GIS tools: ArcGIS Online, Google Earth, Google Maps, ERDAS Imagine, QGIS, Social Explorer, SimplyMap, fusion tables and Tableau.  

  • Proficiency of commonly used geospatial analysis and data-oriented methods, including: data cleaning, data conversions, joining datasets (tables and spatial joins), basic tools like buffers, dissolve, geocoding and georeferencing, thematic mapping, web mapping, understanding coordinate systems, and basic knowledge & skills for finding spatial data.

  • Excellent public service, communication, organizational and interpersonal skills.

 

Preferred Experience:

 

  • Experience teaching GIS software packages and/or research methods.

  • Experience in an academic environment, preferably in IT and/or Libraries.

  • Familiarity with some of geospatial tools and methods, such as: proximity analysis, network analyst, rasters, geostatistical analyst, 3D analyst, business analyst, resource allocation, and model builders.

  • Familiarity with geospatial data related knowledge and tools such as: types of geospatial data, metadata standards and best practices, search and discovery tools, and server-related products.

  • Knowledge and/or experience with a programming language such as Python and/or R.

  • Propensity toward data visualization methods and techniques.

  • Basic understanding of quantitative and qualitative data analysis, and survey research methods.

 

New York University Libraries:

 

Libraries at New York University serve the school’s 40,000 students and faculty and contain more than 5 million volumes. The Libraries supports NYU’s vision to become the first true Global Network University by collaborating and providing services to our 11 global academic centers and “portal campuses” in Abu Dhabi and Shanghai.   New York University Libraries is a member of the Association of Research Libraries, the OCLC Research Library Partnership, and the HathiTrust. The Libraries participates in a variety of consortia and collaborates closely with Columbia University Libraries and the New York Public Library through the Manhattan Research Library Consortium. For the NYU Libraries Mission and Strategic Plan go to http://library.nyu.edu/about/Strategic_Plan.pdf

 

Salary/Benefits:

Salary commensurate with experience and background.

 

To Apply:  

 

To ensure consideration, send resume and letter of application, including the name, address and telephone number of three references to: Enrique Yanez, Director, Human Resources, New York University Libraries, 70 Washington Square South, New York, NY 10012 or via email to jobs@library.nyu.edu. Please include where you heard about this position. The search will remain open until filled.

 

NYU’s Division of Libraries embraces diversity and is committed to attracting qualified candidates who also embrace and value diversity and inclusivity.

 

NYU is an Equal Opportunity/Affirmative Action Employer.

BOX.NAME: Data Services Tutorials
BOX.DESCRIPTION:
Data Services tutorials are typically 60-90 minute sessions that focus on the essential components of our supported software packages. For more information on specific tutorials, and to register, please visit the Data Services section of the Library's classes page. Please note unregistered patrons are welcome to attend our tutorials and will only be asked to leave if there is not enough space to accommodate the attendees who have registered for the session.

A calendar of Data Services' scheduled tutorials and clinics can be found below. Don't see a tutorial you need? Let us know.

BOX.NAME: Test
BOX.DESCRIPTION: A calendar listing when consultants are scheduled to sit at the desks within the Data Services lab can be found below. Please note that the consultants listed in purple are students while those listed in orange are full-time, professional staff members.

BOX.NAME: Data Services Consultant Schedule
BOX.DESCRIPTION:
Data Services consultants are able to provide walk-in assistance when available, however scheduling an appointment ahead of time is highly recommended. For more information on Data Services consultants please refer to the Data Services staff page.

A calendar listing when consultants are scheduled to sit at the desks within the Data Services lab can be found below. Please note that the consultants listed in purple are students while those listed in orange are full-time, professional staff members.

BOX.NAME: Data Services Training
BOX.DESCRIPTION:
Documentation and Resources for Data Services Tutorials

Documentation and supplementary materials for Data Services tutorials can be found below.

Introduction to ArcGIS

  • Tutorial Documentation - A guide covering the majority of topics presented during the Introduction to ArcGIS tutorial (version 10).
  • Spatial Data Repository (SDR) Guides (Access via ArcGIS/ArcMap) (Access via Website).
  • Tutorial Slides - The presentation slides for the tutorial. 
  • Tutorial Feedback Survey for ArcGIS

Introduction to Geocoding

  • Tutorial Slides - The presentation slides for the tutorial.
  • Sample Data - The datasets used for tutorial.

Introduction to R

  • Tutorial Slides - The slides used during the tutorial
  • Tutorial data file - Sample dataset
  • Tutorial syntax - sample syntax

Getting Started with MATLAB

  • Download source code or view as a webpage (also: download sample file for importing)

Introduction to SAS

  • Tutorial Slides - The slides used for the introduction to SAS Tutorial.
  • Sample Code - The follow-along source code to the tutorial slides.
  • Sample Dataset - The dataset used with the sample code.

Introduction to SPSS

  • Tutorial Documentation - A guide that covers the basics of data management in SPSS (version 19).
  • Slides - The slides used for the Introduction to SPSS tutorial.
  • Dataset in SPSS format - The .sav dataset used for the introduction to SPSS tutorial.
  • Sample Syntax File - A sample syntax file used for the introduction to SPSS tutorial.
  • Dataset in CSV format - The dataset used for the above syntax file.

Intermediate Topics in SPSS

  • Tutorial Slides -  The slides used for the intermediate SPSS tutorial.
  • Tutorial Datasets - The .sav data files used during the Intermediate Topics in SPSS tutorial.
  • Tutorial Syntax File - A sample syntax file used for the Intermediate Topics in SPSS tutorial.

Introduction to Stata

  • Tutorial Slides - The slides for the Introduction to Stata tutorial
  • Sample .do File - The .do file used in the Introduction to Stata tutorial.
  • Sample Dataset - The dataset used in the Introduction to Stata tutorial.

Introduction to Qualtrics

  • Tutorial Documentation - A guide that covers the basics of building web-based surveys with Qualtrics.

Getting Started with HPC

  • Tutorial Slides - The presentation slides for the tutorial - covering HPC accounts, basic linux commands, logging into the clusters, moving data to and from the clusters, submitting jobs and monitoring jobs.
    • Sample R Script - A trivial R script to be run on the HPC clusters.
    • Sample PBS Script for R - An example PBS script that runs the above R code.
    • Sample STATA Script - A trivial STATA script to be run on the HPC clusters.
    • Sample PBS Script for STATA - An example PBS script that runs the above STATA code
    • Sample MATLAB Script - A trivial MATLAB script to be run on the HPC clusters.
    • Sample PBS Script for MATLAB - An example PBS script that runs the above MATLAB code

Introduction to Atlas.ti

  • Atlas.ti Tutorial
  • Sample data for tutorials

BOX.NAME: External Training Resources
BOX.DESCRIPTION:
External Training Resources for Supported Software Packages

    If you are looking to learn one our supported software packages, or simply have a question about using one, you are always welcome to contact Data Services; however, we also encourage you to consult some of the Data Services-recommended training resources below.

    ArcGIS

    • ESRI Virtual Campus - A collection of intensive interactive training courses covering everything from the basics of making maps to advanced applications of spatial analysis. NYU's site license with ESRI allows all NYU students, faculty and staff limited access to the attached list of Virtual Campus courses free of cost - please email Data Services (data.services@nyu.edu) with the name(s) of any course(s) you would like attend in order to receive the necessary access codes. Apart from the attached list of courses, a number of free training is also available on ESRI Virtual Campus website.

    ATLAS.ti

    • ATLAS.ti Tutorials - Instructive video tutorials provided by the vendor.

    Google Earth

    • Google Earth "Learn" - Google created and hosted FAQ's and tutorials for Google Earth.

    MATLAB

    • MATLAB Tutorials - Videos, interactive tutorials, user-guides and other instructive resources provided by MathWorks, Universities and others.
    • Interactive Tutorials at MathWorks
    • Recorded Webinars at MathWorks
    • Wikibook on MATLAB Programming

    Python

    • The Python Tutorial - The official introduction to Python tutorial.
    • Google's Python Class - A nice introduction to Python including both text resources and indepth videos.
    • Python for Non-Programmers - A collection of resources for Python users who have little-to-no programming experience.
    • Tutorials Point Python Tutorial - A quick introductory guide to using Python.
    • Introduction to ryp2 - The official tutorial for the ryp2 package, which used to import and manipulate R objects directly from Python.
    • Accessing R from Python with ryp2 - A video introduction to using ryp2 from a LA R users group meeting.
    • Introduction to NumPy - The official NumPy tutorial.
    • NumPy for R Users - A cheat sheet for users familiar with R but using NumPy.
    • NumPy for MATLAB Users - A guide for users familiar with MATLAB but using NumPy.
    • StatsModels Tutorial - An introduction to using the statsmodel module.
    • A Primer on Scientific Programming with Python - An entire ebook (NYUNet access required).

    Qualtrics

    • Qualtrics University - A collection of FAQs, tutorials and scheduled webinars provided by Qualtrics' training staff.

    R

    • R for SPSS and SAS Users - A complete book geared towards teaching R to current SPSS and SAS users.
    • R for Stata Users - A complete book geared towards teaching R to current Stata users.
    • Introductory Statistics with R - An online introductory statistics text using R.
    • Use R! - A collection of online R texts on varying subjects available (on NYUnet) via SpringLink.
    • R Programming Wiki - A detailed wiki with information on statistical computing in R, including information about several external packages.
    • CRAN's Introduction to R Manual - A detailed manual covering the fundamentals of statistical computing in R.
    • UCLA Statistical Computing (R) - A variety of learning modules, FAQ and case examples of using R for statistical computing.
    • Quick-R - A user-friendly reference website full of commonly used R functions, packages and syntax.
    • ggplot2 Reference Manual - A quick reference guide to the popular graphics package ggplots.
    • Cyclismo - A walk-through tutorial that teaches participants the basics of R up through the topics covered in most introductory statistics courses.
    • R-tutor - A user-friendly reference website full of commonly used R functions, packages and syntax.
    • Stackoverflow (R) - A great forum to ask, answer and view questions about R.
    • GitHub (R) - A great forum to post and view user contributed R code.
    • The R Inferno - An excellent manual for more expierenced R programmers.
    • Drew Dimmery's "Thinking in R" presentation slides

    Remark OMR

    • Training Modules - Vendor created videos and self-paced modules for designing forms, creating templates and scanning surveys with Remark OMR.
    • Form Design Basics - General recommendations in order to optimize the results of forms scanned into Remark OMR.

    SAS

    • UCLA Statistical Computing (SAS) - A variety of learning modules, FAQ and case examples of using SAS for statistical computing.
    • Introduction to SAS - Online course materials from STAT 440 at Penn State.
    • SAS Tutorial - A very thorough tutorial by Dr. Dwight Glaster.
    • SAS Video Tutorials - A wide variety of video tutorials hosted by the statistics department of Texas A&M.

    SPSS

    • UCLA Statistical Computing (SPSS) - A variety of learning modules, FAQ and case examples of using SPSS for statistical computing.

    Stata

    • Resources for Learning Stata - A collection of official and user-written training materials.
    • UCLA Statistical Computing (Stata) - A variety of learning modules, FAQ and case examples of using Stata for statistical computing.
    • Stata Tutorial - A well thought Stata tutorial put together by Princeton's Office of Population Research.
    • The Stata Journal - A quarterly publication focusing on articles that using, learning and teaching Stata.
    • Reference Manual - The Stata 12 Reference Manual.

    Statistical Methods (Quick Reference)

    • Statnotes: Topics in Multivariate Analysis by G. David Garson
    • Introductory Statistics: Concepts, Models and Applications by David W. Stockburger
    • Research Methods Knowlegde Base by William M.K. Trochim

    Statistical Methods (Training)

    • ICPSR Summer Program in Quantitative Methods of Social Research: The preeminent forum for basic and advanced training in the methodologies and technologies of social science research. NYU is an ICPSR member institution, entitling NYU affiliates to discounted registration fees.
    • QuantQual.org Methods Mall: A one-stop shop for NSF-sponsored training opportunities in research methods targeted at faculty and graduate students in anthropology (but useful for others too).
